review.title: Universal Dependencies to Logical Forms with Negation Scope
review.abstract: Many language technology applications would benefit from the ability to represent negation and its scope on top of widely-used linguistic resources. In this paper, we investigate the possibility of obtaining a first-order logic representation with negation scope marked using Universal Dependencies. To do so, we enhance UDepLambda, a framework that converts dependency graphs to logical forms. The resulting UDepLambda$\lnot$ is able to handle phenomena related to scope by means of an higher-order type theory, relevant not only to negation but also to universal quantification and other complex semantic phenomena. The initial conversion we did for English is promising, in that one can represent the scope of negation also in the presence of more complex phenomena such as universal quantifiers.

In this paper, we explore the possibility of a logical representation of the first order with a scope of negation characterized by Universal Dependencies. To this end, we expand UDepLambda, a framework that converts dependence graphs into logical forms. The resulting UDepLambda ¬ is able to treat phenomena related to the scope by means of a superior type theory that is relevant not only to denial, but also to universal quantification and other complex semantic phenomena. The original conversion that we have done for English is promising, since the scope of denial can be represented even in the presence of more complex phenomena such as universal quantifiers.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion and future work
sections.text: The conversion processes we present show that it is possible to rely on dependency borders and, in addition, minimal language-dependent lexical information to compose the semantics of the scope of negation. The fact that this formalism is able to correctly compose the scope for many complex phenomena related to the scope of negation is promising. We are currently working to expand this work in two directions: 1. Automatic framework evaluation: In view of the conversion rules presented in this paper, we plan to automatically convert the UD graphs for the sentences in GMB to compare the graph that we automatically generate with a gold standard representation, which would also identify and quantify the errors in our framework. 2. Automatic semantic separation: Given the link between this framework and the GMB, we would like to explore the possibility of forming the conversion in such a way that we do not automatically rely on the conversion.
